courses.course_description: Stresses writing as a process, with due attention given to critical reading and thinking skills applicable to all college classes, as well as to invention, drafting, revising, and rewriting. English 1000 is a prerequisite for any Writing Intensive course.

Stresses writing as a process, with due attention given to critical reading and thinking skills applicable to all college classes, as well as to invention, drafting, revising, and rewriting. English 1000 is a prerequisite for any Writing Intensive course.

(same as ANTHRO 1060, C_S_D 1060 and LINGST 1060). General introduction of various aspects of linguistic study. Elementary analysis of language data, with some attention to application of linguistic study to other disciplines.
Introduces the student to the values, rigors, and pleasures of reading literature. Intended for first-year, non-English majors.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Reading Literature Series.

A basic introduction to the concepts, terms, and practices commonly encountered in literary study, presented by way of texts from the history of British literature that appropriately demonstrate such concepts, terms, and practices. Graded on A-F basis only.

Introduces basic narrative techniques, including writing original stories.

courses.course_name: Creative Writing: Introduction to Nonfiction Prose
courses.course_description: Introduces the range and basic techniques of creative nonfiction, including composing original work in the genre.
Introduces basic poetic techniques, including writing original poems.

(same as ANTHRO 1150).  Course focus is on genres of folklore in both historic and contemporary contexts, as well as in people's daily lives.  Genres include narrative, proverbs, oral poetry and rhyme, riddles, jokes, legends, epics, material culture and intangible expressive culture.  Graded on A/F basis only.

courses.course_name: Introduction to Folklore Genres - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: (same as ANTHRO 1150).  Course focus is on genres of folklore in both historic and contemporary contexts, as well as in people's daily lives.  Genres include narrative, proverbs, oral poetry and rhyme, riddles, jokes, legends, epics, material culture and intangible expressive culture.  Graded on A/F basis only.

(same as FILM_S 1800, DST 1800).  Introduction to terms and concepts for film analysis, including mise-en-scene, cinematography, editing, sound narrative, genre, and other elements. No credit for students who have completed FILM_S 2810.  Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: freshman and sophomores only or instructor's consent

courses.course_description: (same as DST 1880; FILM_S 1880).  Introduction to concepts and skills for Digital Storytelling, including media literacy and forms of narrative manifested historically and currently across a range of media. This course focuses on theories and concepts that support the critical analysis and creation of contemporary narrative in digital form with particular attention to audio, visual and written communication. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.course_name: Theory and Practice of Tutoring Writing Seminar - Honors
courses.course_description: (same as GN_HON 2015H).  Addresses both the theory and practice of tutoring and the foundations of good writing.  This course also qualifies students for a part-time job working as Writing Lab/Online Writery tutors in future semester.

courses.course_description: Introduction to the communication required in any professional field, including basic letters and resumes, reviews, reports, and electronic networking, culminating in an extensive report and a related oral presentation.

A multi-genre survey emphasizing American and British works within the intellectual and cultural context of our time.

(same as BL_STU 2400). Introduces students to African Diaspora literature with an emphasis on literature written originally in English. No more than six hours may be taken in the Introduction to African Diaspora Literature series.

courses.course_description: (same as BL_STU 2407).  See ENGLSH 2400 for course description.

(same as PEA_ST 2490). Introduction to the field of Native Studies. Topics include indigenous knowledge, culture change and continuity, history and misrepresentation, politics and political history, and global indigenous relationships. Graded on A-F basis only.
Provides intensive guided practice in the writing of short fiction.
Provides guided practice in the writing of creative nonfiction.
Provides intensive guided practice in the writing of poetry.
(same as THEATR 2920). Study and practice of playwriting fundamentals; emphasizes the one-act play.

(same as BL_STU 2601, LINGST 2601). Introduction to the diversity of the 2000+ African languages, including first-hand experience exploring a few in detail with native speakers.  Features of African languages are compared with others of the world.  Political and social aspects of language in Africa are discussed.
(same as ANTHRO 2150). Course will focus on the specifics of how to identify, collect, preserve and document folklore within communities.

An introduction to works of verbal art from living oral tradition (e.g. Native American and African-American) and to some of our most important literary works with roots in oral tradition (e.g., the Bible, the Iliad, and the Odyssey, and Beowulf).
(same as FILM_S 2830). Examines the development of American cinema in relation to other national cinemas, from 1895-1950. No credit for students who have completed ENGLSH  1810 or FILM_S 1810.
(same as FILM_S 2840). Examines American film history in an international context, from 1950-present.  No credit for students who have completed ENGLSH 1820 or FILM_S 1820.

(same as FILM_S 2860, DST 2860).  Topics (e.g. Film noir, African-American filmmakers, Food and Film, The Western) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in ENGLSH 2680.

(same as  FILM_S 2870).  Explores the complex interplay between film and literature in order to gain an understanding of the possibilities - and problems - involved in the transposition from literature to film.  Graded on A-F basis only.

(same as DST 2880). Digital Storytelling Production I teaches agility with digital video technology through applied experiences. Assignments in digital video production emphasize how video narratives are created and how images and audio enhance the structure, mood, and theme of the narrative. Instruction will focus on planning a video production and developing the tools and practices in lighting, sound recording, image capturing, and editing. Graded on A-F basis only.

(same as DST 2885). Introduction to all aspects of digital animation and elements of the 3D computer animation production pipeline, including story drafting and production planning, polygonal modeling and texturing, rigging, key framing, lighting, compositing rendered images, and editing into a short finished film. Graded on A-F basis only.

Students perform volunteer service and complete course requirements, which may include class meetings and written and oral assignments. May be repeated with departmental consent. Graded on a S/U basis only. Does not meet A&S general education requirements.
An intensive writing workshop in which student essays and related texts receive close reading and analysis. Focus (e.g. The Essay, The Research Paper) announced at time of registration.

(same as [WGST] 3080). Examination of major theoretical approaches and debates in the study of gender and sexuality, with particular attention to the intersection of culture, representation, and identity. May be repeated to 6 hours with department consent.

Introduction to the range of theoretical approaches to the study of literature; intended as a broad survey of literary theory, whether from the Classical era onward or 20th century literary theory and beyond.
Topics (e.g., Postmodernism, Representations of Nature) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Special Themes in Literature series.

courses.course_name: Survey of British Literature: Beginnings to 1784
courses.course_description: Historical survey from beginnings of British literature through the age of Johnson, with readings representing significant writers, works and currents of thought.

courses.course_name: Survey of British Literature: Romanticism to the Present
courses.course_description: Historical survey of British literature from the Romantic period to the present, emphasizing important writers and significant intellectual and cultural movements.

courses.course_name: Survey of British Literature: Romanticism to the Present - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: Historical survey of British literature from the Romantic period to the present, emphasizing important writers and significant intellectual and cultural movements.

courses.course_name: Survey of American Literature: Beginnings to 1865
courses.course_description: A survey of major writers and movements in American literature from Colonialism to Romanticism.

courses.course_description: A survey of major writers and movements in American literature from Colonialism to Romanticism.
A survey of major writers and movements in American literature from realism to postmodernism.

courses.course_name: Survey of American Literature: 1865-Present - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: A survey of major writers and movements in American literature from realism to postmodernism.

courses.course_name: Survey of African American Literature, Beginnings to 1900
courses.course_description: (same as BL_STU 3400). A survey of major authors and movements in African American literature from its beginnings to 1900.

courses.course_name: Survey of African American Literature, Beginnings to 1900 - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: (same as BL_STU 3400). A survey of major authors and movements in African American literature from its beginnings to 1900.
(same as BL_STU 3410). A survey of major authors and movements in African American literature from 1900 to the present.

courses.course_name: Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature
courses.course_description: (same as BL_STU 3420). Topic (e.g. Harlem Renaissance African Diaspora  Poetry) Announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature series.

courses.course_name: Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature, 1603 to 1789
courses.course_description: (same as BL_STU 3427).  See ENGLSH 3420 for course description.

courses.course_name: Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature, 1789 to 1890
courses.course_description: (same as BL_STU 3428).  See ENGLSH 3420 for course description.

courses.course_name: Periods and Genres in African Diaspora Literature, 1890 to Present
courses.course_description: (same as BL_STU 3429).  See ENGLSH 3420 for course description.

courses.course_name: Introduction to African Diaspora Literary Theory
courses.course_description: (same as BL_STU 3705).  Introduction to the range of theoretical approaches to the study of African Diaspora literature, with particular attention to the diverse socio-political contexts that undergird range of literary, historical, and cultural theories; intended as a broad survey of African Diaspora literary theory, whether from the Slavery era onward or 20th century literary theory and beyond. May be repeated for credit with consent.

(same as PEA_ST 3490).  Survey of native writing and representation from the late eighteenth century to the present, encompassing a diverse range of tribes and forms. Material will be drawn from tribes inhabiting the North American continent, but global indigenous relationships will also be addressed. Graded on A-F basis only.
(same as THEATR 3920). Intermediate study of the writing process as applied to theatre, leading to the creation of a full-length play to be considered for production.
(same as COMMUN 3570 and THEATR 3200). Analysis and oral interpretation of literary works. Graded on A-F basis only.
(same as ANTHRO 3150). Focus on regional and ethnic folklore; emphasis on analysis of folklore in context. Requirements include book reports and two analytical papers based on student field research.

(same as FILM_S 3820, RM_LAN 3820). Topics (e.g. Hitchcock, Kubrick, Fellini, Allen, Kurosawa, Wilder) announced at time of registration.  Only 6 hours may be taken for credit toward major.  Graded on A/F basis only.

(same as  FILM_S 3850).  Topics (e.g. Classical Period of Hollywood cinema, silent era, Post-WWII American film, German Weimar cinema, French New Wave) announced at time of registration.  Only 6 hours count as credit toward major.

(same as FILM_S 3855, DST 3855).  Surveys the history of documentary film including the development of subgenres, sound and voice over in documentary, re-enactment, ethical issues in documentary film production, and more.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.course_name: Writing and Theory for Digital Media
courses.course_description: (same as DST 3880). Writing and Theory for Digital Media teaches the skills, methods and theoretical frameworks needed to write for new media. Students will study and practice writing for web-based and digital media platforms, including short-form modes such as Twitter and various social media sites; longer-form modes such as blogs, vlogs and podcasts; and the emerging possibilities of locative and interactive media. Assignments emphasize the professional and creative possibilities of new media production. In addition to the hands-on creation for audio, screen-based, networked, and hybrid forms of digital media, students will also read, discuss, and write about work by new media theorists. Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.course_name: Writing and Theory for Digital Media  - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: methods and theoretical frameworks needed to write for new media. Students will study and practice writing for web-based and digital media platforms, including short-form modes such as Twitter and various social media sites; longer-form modes such as blogs, vlogs and podcasts; and the emerging possibilities of locative and interactive media. Assignments emphasize the professional and creative possibilities of new media production. In addition to the hands-on creation for audio, screen-based, networked, and hybrid forms of digital media, students will also read, discuss, and write about work by new media theorists. Graded on A-F basis only.
Advanced examination of subjects within English studies. Subjects vary from semester to semester. May repeat to six hours.

courses.course_name: Advanced Studies in English - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: Advanced examination of subjects within English studies. Subjects vary from semester to semester. May repeat to six hours.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May repeat to six hours.

(cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7040). A hybrid reading/writing course that focuses on a form of nonfiction prose, such as the experimental essay, art criticism, book reviews, spiritual writing, nature writing, etc. This course is not a workshop, although it may incorporate workshop elements. Designed for English majors who may or may not have taken creative writing courses. May repeat to six hours with departmental consent.

A hybrid reading/writing course that focuses on a form of nonfiction prose, such as the experimental essay, art criticism, book reviews, spiritual writing, nature writing, etc. This course is not a workshop, although it may incorporate workshop elements. Designed for English majors who may or may not have taken creative writing courses. May repeat to six hours with departmental consent.

Examines questions  related to rhetoric, the study of symbols used for persuasion, justification, or communication.  Specific topics are announced at time of registration and may involve the rhetorical study of fiction or nonfiction, oral or written texts, verbal or visual modes.
A survey of major works of rhetoric from Plato to the present day, with special attention to those works influencing English language rhetorics and theories of rhetoric.
Focuses on questions raised by various critical theories, includes practice writing criticism that applies the theories to particular works. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.
Surveys modern and contemporary theories of literary criticism: historical, archetypal, generic, formalist, phenomenological and interdisciplinary. Emphasizes key writers in each field.

Advanced survey of major movements and writers. Topics (e.g., American Poetry, The Development of the British Novel) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Genres series.

Advanced survey of major movements and writers. Topics (e.g., American Poetry, The Development of the British Novel) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Genres series.

(same as WGST 4181 and BL_STU 4181). Examines works by a number of women writers with particular attention to their socio-political context. May repeated to six hours with department's consent.

(cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7206). Readings in the literature of Anglo-Saxon England (ca.500-ca.1100 C.E.). Specific topics (e.g., Women in the Early Middle Ages, Beowulf, Old English Heroic Poetry) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.
(cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7210). Topics (e.g., Age of Chaucer, Chivalry and Courtly Love, Allegory and Satire) announced at time of registration. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.
Topics (e.g., The Metaphysical Poets, Themes in Shakespeare) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Renaissance and Seventeenth Century Literature.

courses.course_description: In-depth study of topics in Native American and Indigenous Studies, such as tribal intellectual histories, defined historical periods, or specific genres or media.  Examples of course titles include Ojibwe Writing, Native Film and Video, and Contemporary Native Literature.
An intensive writing workshop in which student stories and related literary texts receive close reading and analysis.

courses.course_name: Creative Writing: Advanced Fiction - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: An intensive writing workshop in which student stories and related literary texts receive close reading and analysis.
An intensive writing workshop in which a student's creative nonfiction receives close reading and analysis.

courses.course_name: Creative Writing: Advanced Nonfiction Prose - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: An intensive writing workshop in which a student's creative nonfiction receives close reading and analysis.
Poetry regarded as a mode of understanding. Poetic values related to other values. Practical consideration of verse techniques.

courses.course_name: Creative Writing: Advanced Poetry - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: Poetry regarded as a mode of understanding. Poetic values related to other values. Practical consideration of verse techniques.

(same as THEATR 4920; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7560 and THEATR 7920). Advanced study of the writing process as applied to theatre, including theory and practice. Special playwriting problems and techniques.

(same as THEATR 4920; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7560 and THEATR 7920). Advanced study of the writing process as applied to theatre, including theory and practice. Special playwriting problems and techniques.

courses.course_name: Adaptation of Literature for the Stage
courses.course_description: (same as THEATR 4930; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7570 and THEATR 7930). Explores adaptation principles and practices with literature not originally written for the stage.  Graded on A-F basis only.
(same as LINGST 4600). Introduction to English linguistics. Study of the grammar and pronunciation of contemporary English, with the major focus on syntax.
(same as LINGST 4610). Historical changes in the grammar and pronunciation of the English language from Old English to the present. Introduction to Indo-European origins of English.

courses.course_name: Regional and Social Dialects of American English
courses.course_description: (same as LINGST 4620). The study of regional and social variation in pronunciation, vocabulary, and grammar of American English.
(same as LINGST 4630). Survey of the sound patterns of English, with some comparison to other languages.
(same as LINGST 4640). Study of the properties of phrase-and sentence-level grammar, emphasizing English, with some comparison to other languages.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 4600 or another comparable linguistics course

courses.course_description: (same as LINGST 4870 and ANTHRO 4870). Provides training in the methods of constructing a detailed linguistic description and analysis of wholly unfamiliar language, based on interviews with a native speaker.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.

courses.course_name: Field Methods in Linguistics - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: (same as LINGST 4870 and ANTHRO 4870). Provides training in the methods of constructing a detailed linguistic description and analysis of wholly unfamiliar language, based on interviews with a native speaker.  May be repeated for credit.  Graded on A-F basis only.

(same as ANTHRO 4150). Intensive study in a selected area of folklore: folk narrative, folk song, myth, proverb, etc., folklore of a particular group. May be repeated for a maximum of six hours with department's consent.

(same as ANTHRO 4160 and BL_STU 4710). Intensive study in a selected area of African Diaspora folklore: folk narrative, folk song, myth, proverb, etc., folklore and literature; or the folklore of a particular group. ENGLSH 4700 and ENGLSH 4710 may be repeated for a maximum of six hours with instructor's consent.

(same as CL_HUM 4770). Study of verbal art from living oral traditions (e.g., Native American and African American) and important literary works with roots in oral tradition (e.g., the Bible, the Iliad, the Odyssey, and Beowulf).

(same as WGST 4780). Examines folklore and artistic expression of women in relation to feminist theory and in multicultural contexts. Includes verbal genres (narrative/ song) as well as material genres (quilting/arts).

(same as FILM_S 4810, DST 4810). This course explores contemporary trends in film theory. Topics may include: psychoanalysis, feminism, Marxism, cultural studies, queer theory, audience and star studies, postcolonialism, among others.
(same as FILM_S 4820). Topics (e.g. The Western, Film Noir) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken for credit toward the major.

(same as FILM_S 4840, DST 4840). Topics (e.g. Cinema and Imperialism, Indigenous Media, Ethnographic Documentary) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken for credit toward the major.

(same as DST 4880). Digital Storytelling Production II introduces students to advanced techniques in digital storytelling production, while further developing skills in script writing, storyboarding, Adobe Premiere Pro, and video production with DSLR cameras. Assignments in digital video production emphasize how video narratives are created and how images and audio enhance the structure, mood, and theme of the narrative. Instruction will focus on planning a video production and developing the tools and practices in lighting, sound recording, image capturing, and editing. Graded on A-F basis only.
courses.prerequisites: ENGLSH 1000, ENGLSH 1880/DST 1880, and sophomore standing, or consent of instructor

courses.course_description: (same as FILM_S 4935 and THEATR 4935; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7580, FILM_S 7935 and THEATR 7935). This upper-division course will explore adaptation principles and practices with a variety of forms of literature that were not originally written for film.

(same as THEATR 4938; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 7938, THEATR 7938). Students develop advanced skills of screenwriting through a focus on non-realistic, non-linear dramatic writing styles in development of a full-length screenplay. Areas of study will include techniques of magic realism, symbolism, expressionism, absurdism, surrealism/dada, mythic/fantasy, musicals, political docudrama, and science fiction.
Students work in an agency or institution using their English-related skills for one to three credit hours. Graded on an S/U basis only.

Offers practical experience working with a literary or scholarly publication edited or sponsored by faculty members. Graduate students in English must take the course two semesters in order to count three hours toward the completion of their program.
Development of a carefully considered research project under close supervision of a faculty member. Open to undergraduate students only.
Individual work with conferences adjusted to needs of student.

For students in their last semester, this course focuses on a major project and the processes of selection, research, and writing leading to its completion. Includes a professional component (resume, cover letter).

For students in their last semester, this course focuses on a major project and the processes of selection, research, and writing leading to its completion. Includes a professional component (resume, cover letter).
Independent research under direction of faculty.  Second course of two part Honors Sequence.
First of two major semester Honors sequence.  Studies literary topic, critical approaches and advanced literary research methodology in preparation for Honors Senior Thesis.

courses.course_name: Honors Seminar in English - Writing Intensive
courses.course_description: First of two major semester Honors sequence.  Studies literary topic, critical approaches and advanced literary research methodology in preparation for Honors Senior Thesis.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester. May repeat to six hours.

(cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4040). A hybrid reading/writing course that focuses on a form of nonfiction prose, such as the experimental essay, art criticism, book reviews, spiritual writing, nature writing, etc. This course is not a workshop, although it may incorporate workshop elements. Designed for students who may or may not have taken previous creative writing courses. May repeat to six hours with departmental consent.

Examines questions related to rhetoric, the study of symbols used for persuasion, justification, or communication.  Specific topics are announced at time of registration and may involve the rhetorical study of fiction or nonfiction, oral or written texts, verbal or visual modes.
A survey of major works of rhetoric from Plato to the present day, with special attention to those works influencing English language rhetoric's and theories of rhetoric.
Focuses on questions raised by various critical theories, includes practice writing criticism that applies the theories to particular works. May repeat to six hours with departmental consent.
Surveys modern and contemporary theories of literary criticism: historical, archetypal, generic, formalist, phenomenological and interdisciplinary. Emphasizes key writers in each field.

Advanced survey of major movements and writers. Topics (e.g., American Poetry, The Development of the British Novel) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the Genres series.
See ENGLSH 7100 for course description.
See ENGLSH 7100 for course description.

Explores in depth the literary traditions of one of America's minority ethnic cultures: Native American, African-American, Hispanic American, Asian American.   No more than six hours may be taken in the Ethnic Literature series.
See ENGLSH 7120 for course description.
See ENGLSH 7120 for course description.
See ENGLSH 7120 for course description.
A study of selected twentieth-century literature within the intellectual and cultural contexts of the modern era.

Study of important works and writers from Asia, Africa, Europe, Latin America or the mid-East. Topics (e.g., Survey of World Literature, The Bible) announced at time of registration.  No more than six hours may be taken in the World Literatures series.
See ENGLSH 7150 for course description.

Study of works separated by the places or eras of their composition, but united by themes or traditions. Topics (e.g., Poets of African Diaspora, Literatures of Exile) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken in the Comparative Approaches to Literature Series.

(same as WGST 7181). Examines works by a number of women writers with particular attention to their socio-political context. May repeat to six hours with department's consent.

(same as ANTHRO 7160 and [BL_STU 7710). Intensive study in a selected area of African Diaspora folklore: folk narrative, folk song, myth, proverb, etc., folklore and literature; or the folklore of a particular group. ENGLSH 7700 and ENGLSH 7710 may be repeated for a maximum of six hours with instructor's consent.

(same as CL_HUM 4770). Study of verbal art from living oral traditions (e.g., Native American and African American) and important literary works with roots in oral tradition (e.g., the Bible, the Iliad the Odyssey, and Beowulf).

(same as WGST 7780). Examines folklore and artistic expression of women in relation to feminist theory and in multicultural contexts. Includes verbal genres (narrative/ song) as well as material genres (quilting/arts).

(same as FILM_S 7810).   This course explore contemporary trends in film theory.  Topics may include: psychoanalysis, feminism, Marxism, cultural studies, queer theory, audience and star studies, postcolonialism, among others.  Graded on A-F basis only.

(same as FILM_S 7840). Topics (e.g. Cinema and Imperialism, Indigenous Media, Ethnographic Documentary) announced at time of registration. No more than six hours may be taken for credit toward the major.

(same as THEATR 7938; cross-leveled with ENGLSH 4938, THEATR 4938).  Students develop advanced skills of screenwriting through a focus on non-realistic, non-linear dramatic writing styles in development of a full-length screenplay. Areas of study will include techniques of magic realism, symbolism, expressionism, absurdism, surrealism/dada, mythic/fantasy, musicals, political docudrama, and science fiction.

Offers practical experience working with a literary or scholarly publication edited or sponsored by faculty members. Graduate students in English must take the course two semesters in order to count three hours toward the completion of their program.
Organized study of selected topics. Subjects and earnable credit may vary from semester to semester.
Introduces entering MA and PhD students to the profession of English and the intellectual resources needed to complete their degrees successfully.
Introduces advanced graduate students to issues relevant to their professional training, including entering the job market and preparing work for publication.  May be repeated for credit.
Current and historical theories of rhetoric and composition as applied to the teaching of college composition.
Topics (e.g., The Institutionalization of Rhetoric, Writing Across the Curriculum) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.
A survey of contemporary professional critical methods, such as formalism, poststructuralism, feminism, Marxism, new historicism, psychoanalysis, identity studies, and cultural studies.
Principles and practices of selected critics. May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.

A survey of the history of literary criticism and theory. While comprehensive in scope, the course might focus on specific topics in the history of criticism, such as the dialectic between rhetoric and poetics, the rise of aesthetics, or the relation of art and culture to society. Figures studied will extend from early philosophers such as Plato and Aristotle, through eighteenth-century thinkers such as Kant and Johnson, up to present theorists such as Derrida and Butler.
Leads to preparation of masters thesis. Graded on S/U basis only.
Individual work not leading to preparation of dissertation.
Topics (e.g., The Epic, The Epistolary Novel) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

Topics in Old English or Anglo-Saxon literature, such as Beowulf, the Exeter Book poems, or the genres of elegy, Biblical narrative, or wisdom poetry. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.
Topics (e.g., Medieval Drama, Chaucer) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.
Topics (e.g., Tudor and Stuart Drama, Shakespearean Tragedy) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.
Topics (e.g., The Metaphysical Poets, Restoration Drama) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.
Topics (e.g., The 18th-Century Novel, Historical and Biographical Prose) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.
Topics (e.g., The Later Romantics, Victorian Poetry) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.
Topics (e.g., Chief Contemporary Poets, Modernism and the Novel) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.
Topics (e.g., Religious and Philosophical Writings, The Revolutionary Period) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.
Topics (e.g., The Transcendentalists, American Realism) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.
Topics (e.g., The African-American Novel, Chief Contemporary Poets) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.
(same as BL_STU 8400). Topic (e.g., Autobiography, Black Women Writers) announced at time of registration. May be repeated to 12 hours with departmental consent.

courses.course_name: Seminar in African Diaspora Theory and Literature Criticism
courses.course_description: (same as BL_STU 8410). Modern and contemporary African Diaspora criticism and theory including the diverse approaches to literary and cultural studies. May be repeated to 12 hours with departmental consent.
Advanced fiction writing designed primarily for graduate students, with the intention of producing work of professional quality. May repeat to twelve hours with consent of instructor.
Advanced workshop in nonfiction prose primarily for graduate students intending to produce professional quality work.
Advanced poetry writing designed primarily for graduate students with the intention of producing work of professional quality. May repeat to twelve hours with consent of instructor.

(same as THEATR 8920). Seminar in theory, practice, and pedagogy of playwriting, students a mid-term in playwriting theory, a full-length play, a research paper, and a syllabus and lesson plans for an undergraduate playwriting course.

(same as LINGST 8600). Descriptive and historical studies of the English language. Topics (e.g., The Germanic Origins, Modern Syntactic Analysis) announced at time of registration. May repeat to twelve hours with department's approval.

(same as ANTHRO 8157 and REL_ST 8700). Focus on the roots of folklore scholarship and methodology and their evolution in modern approaches to the study of oral, traditional verbal genres and their performance in natural folk groups.  May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.

Theoretical and interpretive perspectives on works of verbal art that have roots in oral tradition. Emphasis on the variety of approaches employed (performance theory oral theory, ethnopoetics, ethnography of speaking, comparative structural studies, etc.) May repeat to twelve hours with department's consent.
Leads to preparation of dissertation. Graded on S/U basis only.
